{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3341438,"name":"","username":"sfvel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sfvel/{size}/204265_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-23T18:30:44.080Z","cooked":"

Screenshot 2024-03-23 1419571920×1005 187 KB

Ever since the recent Limelight OS update (2024.3.4), AdvantageScope incorrectly interprets the botpose_wpiblue double array published to the NT. Our team uses botpose_wpiblue double array exclusively so I can’t speak on the other arrays, but based on the documentation my best guess is that those arrays will also have issues.

Limelight OS 2024.3.4 added new information to these arrays, which are just added on to the original information about the target. This new information is based on how many tags there are. If more tags are in view, the array will be longer because information from each tag is being added. When trying to visualize the array in AdvantageScope, multiple robots show up on the 3D Field tab. Our guess is that AdvantageScope is seeing this longer-than-normal array and thinking it is more poses.

Are there any quick fixes we can do on our end to only visualize the pose? Is there potential for a fix from AdvantageScope in the next 2-3 days? We are logging this data as well, and want the visualization to work when we playback logs.

You can construct a new pose array from the limelight pose. It should be in the following double array format:
[x, y, rot]

Limelight’s botpose measurements have never been compatible with AdvantageScope, since they publish the 3D pose with the wrong format (roll, pitch, yaw instead of a quaternion). Your best bet is to publish the pose with the correct 2D or 3D format documented here. This also allows you to use structured data types instead of the legacy array format, making it harder to mix up data types (Limelight has not adopted structured data for their native publishing either).
